channel.title: puppeteer on Nicole van der Hoeven
channel.description: Recent content in puppeteer on Nicole van der Hoeven

item.title: Cuándo JMeter no alcanza: Pruebas de carga simulando navegadores
item.description: Aquí está el video de mi presentación en JMeter Scripting Day, un evento organizado por JMeter en Español el 31 de Oktubre, 2020. Y la versión audio: Introducción Hola a todos! Yo soy Nicole van der Hoeven, y soy performance tester. JMeter es una de mis herramientas favoritas porque es gratis, simple, y por muchos casos hace exactamente lo que quiero y no más. Sin embargo, como performers es parte de nuestro trabajo elegir la herramienta adecuada para cada proyecto, y hay que admitir que hay situaciones en que JMeter simplemente no es suficiente.

item.title: Ask a Flooder 16: How do I use test data with Element?
item.description: Originally posted on Tricentis Flood. In this video, I discuss how to make your load testing scripts more realistic by including test data. The load testing tool I use is Flood Element, but you can apply these principles to any tool. You’ll find a copy of the Element script I used below. ‍ And, if you prefer, here’s the audio version: Transcript Hi everyone, Nicole van der Hoeven here back with another Ask a Flooder, and this time the question is: How do I use test data with Flood Element?

item.title: Ask a Flooder 15: How do I install Element?
item.description: Originally posted here. In this Flood Element tutorial, I demonstrate the steps required to install Flood Element, including dependencies it requires. Flood Element is an open-source browser-based load testing tool created by Tricentis Flood. Learn more about Flood Element Installation instructions for NodeJS Installation instructions for Yarn Installation instructions for Element Video: Getting Started with Element Guides: Using Element with Flood‍ Audio version here: Transcript Hi everyone, Nicole van der Hoeven here again, back with another Ask a Flooder, and today’s question is: “How do I install Element?

item.title: Browser-based load testing in 2020
item.description: Originally posted here. We first announced our open-source browser-based load testing tool based on Puppeteer, Flood Element, in February 2018. Despite our decision to make it an entirely separate tool from Flood, we’ve enjoyed using it so much as a team that several of us have written about it: Tim Koopmans: Load testing for DevOps… with Browser Level Users (BLU) Kevin Dunne: A new approach to load testing with browser level users

item.title: Ask a Flooder 12: Puppeteer vs Selenium: which one is better for load testing?
item.description: When it comes to software testing, the debate of Puppeteer vs Selenium is a hot one. Nicole tackles it here to determine which one is better for load testing in particular. Spoiler: The answer is still “it depends”. Or catch the audio version here: Hi everyone, Nicole here again, back for another Ask a Flooder, and today, the question is: “Puppeteer vs. Selenium: which one is better for load testing?
